title: Republicans set up showdown after setting vote on flood bills with Democrats absent
description: The movement of flood-related bills in the Texas House on Monday could amp up political pressure on Democrats who have left the state to block redistricting.
content:
AUSTIN — Texas House Republicans teed up a slate of bills addressing the deadly July 4 Hill Country floods on Monday, but Democrats’ continued boycott left the chamber without the quorum needed to vote — setting the stage for Republicans to use the flood relief measures as leverage against their absent colleagues.

The Texas House has remained at an impasse since Aug. 4, after enough Democrats refused to show up at the Capitol to block a vote on a partisan congressional redistricting proposal. So far, Democrats’ denial of a constitutionally required two-thirds quorum has blocked only redistricting.

But Monday’s advancement of five bills related to the floods now hands Republicans fresh political leverage in their attempts to convince enough Democrats to return to the Austin to restore a quorum in the Texas House.

The flood bills are set for a vote Tuesday. The five pieces of legislation include House Bill 1, which requires the state to develop a mass fatality training program for justices of the peace in counties without a medical examiner.

Other flood-related proposals advanced Monday would address first responders’ communications, expand a taxpayer fund for broadband access or response, communications and early warning systems in disasters and other emergencies, require some riverside campgrounds to develop disaster plans and combat disaster relief fraud.

The July 4 floods killed at least 137 people. The damage was most severe in Kerr County, where 27 children and counselors were killed at an all-girls summer camp near Hunt.

At a news conference Monday in northwest Chicago, Rep. Gene Wu, a Houston Democrat and chair of the House Democratic Caucus, said absent Democrats would return to Texas if flood bills are placed ahead of redistricting.

“We have said point blank, time after time after time that if Gov. [Greg] Abbott says, ‘We will take care of the people of the state of Texas first,’ – if he makes that commitment today, we’ll be back,” Wu said.

House Democrats were joined by Illinois Sen. Dick Durbin Monday. The quorum breakers had intended to meet with Durbin last week, but canceled the event after a bomb threat was made to the St. Charles, Ill., hotel where they had been staying.

They have since moved to a secret location in the Chicago area.

Rep. Mihaela Plesa, D-Dallas, said that since the bomb threat, her colleagues have received racist attacks. Texas Republican leaders, including Abbott, Attorney General Ken Paxton and Sen. John Cornyn have also taken action against Democrats with lawsuits and calling on the FBI to track them.

House Speaker Dustin Burrows issued civil arrest warrants for absent Democrats, empowering state law enforcement to force them to return to the Capitol. Paxton has filed a pair of lawsuits in an attempt to require law enforcement in Illinois and California to enforce those warrants.

Plesa said state law enforcement has visited her North Dallas home multiple times, including Monday morning. Abbott posted a wanted poster of Plesa Monday on social media. She is one of 13 House members Paxton is trying to remove from office.

“We will not be intimidated,” Plesa said. “We will not be bullied into silence, and we will not surrender like the governor has to the demands of corrupt DC politicians.”

The Texas House was set to meet at 1 p.m. Monday. The redistricting proposal was set for another vote.

It would transform three Democratically held districts, including a North Texas seat represented by Rep. Julie Johnson, D-Farmers Branch, from liberal strongholds to districts that would sharply favor Republicans.

Two South Texas swing districts would also be shifted to the right.

Trump has called on Texas lawmakers to flip at least five Democratic seats to Republican control in hopes of maintaining a GOP majority in the U.S. House of Representatives in next year’s midterm election.
summary: Texas House Republicans have advanced five bills related to the July 4 Hill Country floods, which killed at least 137 people. Democrats' continued boycott has left the chamber without a quorum, allowing Republicans to use these measures as leverage. The legislation includes a mass fatality training program for justices of the peace in counties without a medical examiner. Other flood-related measures include expanding a taxpayer fund for broadband access or response, requiring some riverside campgrounds to develop disaster plans and combating disaster relief fraud. The Texas House has been at an impasse since Aug. 4 due to Democrats' refusal to participate in a vote on a partisan congressional redistricting proposal. The Republican leaders have taken legal action against Democrats, including Abbott, Attorney General Ken Paxton and Sen. John Cornyn, and have issued civil arrest warrants for absent Democrats.
shortSummary: Texas House Republicans advanced flood relief bills amid a Democratic boycott, using the absence of colleagues to leverage for broader political gains.

Texas Republicans have proposed a redistricting plan that would eliminate one Democratically held seat each from Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston and the Austin/San Antonio area.
District lines would also be redrawn in South Texas, pushing two seats currently held by Democrats toward stronger Republican majorities, according to an analysis based on 2024 election results.
The plan also further condenses some urban Democratic strongholds. The result would create two majority Black districts — Congressional District 30, currently represented by Rep. Jasmine Crockett, D-Dallas, and Congressional District 18 in Houston, a vacant seat that was represented by Rep. Sylvester Turner until his death in March. They would be the only two majority Black congressional districts in Texas.
The map’s release unleashed intense criticism from Democrats, raising the prospect of blue states like California redrawing their boundaries to offset Republican gains in Texas. Democrats in the Texas Legislature fled the state Sunday in order to delay or prevent a vote on the plan.
Texas Gov. Greg Abbott on Sunday threatened to remove from office Democratic lawmakers who don’t show up when the House convenes Monday afternoon.
President Donald Trump has called on Texas lawmakers to change boundaries that he believes could result in Republicans gaining as many as five seats now held by Democrats and help the GOP maintain control of Congress in the 2026 midterm elections. Midterms generally favor the party out of power in the White House, and in 2026 are expected to favor Democrats.
More subtle changes are made to two Democrat-held districts in South Texas, where Republicans appear to be betting their gains among Latino communities will hold steady.
The three urban districts see the most drastic changes. Johnson’s seat, for instance, is a relatively compact district containing parts of Dallas surrounding White Rock Lake, as well as suburban areas in Richardson, Addison and Plano that have shifted toward Democrats in recent years.
It would be redrawn to stretch from Carrollton eastward to the rural city of Gilmer, a two-and-a-half-hour drive between the two cities. The resulting district would shift 41 percentage points to the right, transforming from a district that heavily favored former Vice President Kamala Harris in 2024’s election to one that would have voted for Trump by nearly 18 points.

ST. CHARLES, Ill. — Leaving behind his nearly nine months pregnant wife, Kendall Scudder trekked to Tulsa, Okla., on June 28 to meet with Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker.
Scudder, the newly elected chair of the Texas Democratic Party, arranged to have a private meeting with the governor at the site of a fundraiser for Oklahoma Democrats, where Pritzker was a keynote speaker. One of the topics he wished to broach was a persistent rumor circulating in Austin for months: redistricting.
“I knew that we needed to start forming relationships with partners outside the state in the event that we needed to use those relationships,” Scudder said.
Five weeks later, Scudder had a 2-week-old son, Lyndon — named for the former president and his wife’s father — and an exodus of state House Democrats from Texas was underway, with dozens secretly fleeing to Illinois to block a vote on a partisan gerrymander that could flip as many as five Democratic-held seats to Republican control.
For the past week, the Texas House has been at a standstill after Democrats refused to show up on Aug. 4, denying the chamber a constitutionally required quorum to conduct legislative business. Their move — known as a quorum break — blocked a vote on congressional redistricting sought by President Donald Trump, as well as more than a dozen other items Gov. Greg Abbott placed on a special session agenda — most notably efforts to address the Hill Country floods that killed at least 137 people.
The Dallas Morning News spoke with more than 20 House Democrats and staff who have been decamped in Illinois for the past week. Their accounts offer an inside look at how they decided to employ the nuclear option to block redistricting and how they pushed redistricting into the national spotlight amid Republican backlash and growing security concerns.
The rumors
Rep. Ramon Romero Jr., D-Fort Worth, said he first heard rumors of redistricting in the early spring. Education policy dominated the session. It seemed there would be little room for something as politically thorny as redistricting.
“No one really took it seriously,” Romero said.
Democrats dismissed the rumors in part because the Legislature approved redistricting in 2021, further solidifying Republican majorities in both chambers of the state Legislature and adding two more seats for Republicans to Washington.
The rumors lulled, but returned in late May during the final weeks of the biennial 140-day session of the Texas Legislature.
Rep. Gene Wu, chair of the House Democratic Caucus, said the session came to a close, and he heard Abbott might try to redistrict Texas in a special session.
“I’m like, ‘What special?’” Wu said.
After the session ended, Abbott issued an 11th-hour veto of a ban on hemp-derived THC products. Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick was incensed over the torpedoing of what is one of his top legislative priorities. But it also gave Abbott a clear path to call a special 30-day legislative session.
Abbott had made an initial list of items he told lawmakers would appear in an upcoming special session. THC was on the list. Redistricting wasn’t.
But then the July 4 floods came. That, Wu said, was when whispers of redistricting rose to a roar.
“People in the know realized that Abbott would use the Kerrville disaster as cover to do redistricting,” Wu said. “That’s when the hairs on the back of my neck went up and I kind of said, ‘Oh, crap.’”
Abbott spokesman Andrew Mahaleris said in a statement that Democrats’ flight from the state was a “publicity stunt,” and that the governor has “deployed all available resources and support to help communities respond and recover.” Any relief funds, Mahaleris added, would need to be appropriated by the Legislature.
“If Texas House Democrats care about the Texans they abandoned, they will return to Austin and do the job they were elected to do,” he said.
The maps
On July 7, the U.S. Department of Justice penned a letter to Abbott and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton stating that four congressional districts in Texas violated new caselaw on the Voting Rights Act of 1965 that weakened legal claims protecting “coalition districts” — districts in which a combination of nonwhite communities comprises a majority.
Two days later, Abbott called a special session that included redistricting, citing the DOJ letter in his proclamation.
The session began on July 21, and legislative hearings on redistricting started rapidly.
Over nine days, the House and Senate held nine hearings on redistricting. Most occurred before the proposed map was made available to lawmakers and the public. They included hearings in Austin, Houston and Arlington.
At every hearing, lawmakers heard near-universal opposition to the plan. Democrats on the committees lodged bitter complaints, at times calling the effort a racist attempt to disenfranchise people of color. Rep. Chris Turner, D-Grand Prairie, described the public hearings as a “dog and pony show.”
Republican heads of the committees disagreed with the Justice Department’s conclusion that the 2021 maps violated the Voting Rights Act. But those same leaders said the disagreement was a moot point, pointing to U.S. Supreme Court rulings in 2019 and 2024 that stated political gerrymanders were legal as long as race was not taken into account.
“I frankly don’t care what the DOJ letter said, and I think it’s pretty clear that no one does on the prevailing side of this bill,” said the chair of the House redistricting committee, Rep. Cody Vasut, R-Angelton. “This bill was not based off of that DOJ letter. It was based off of political performance.”
When the maps were revealed on July 30 in House Bill 4, the proposal showed redrawn districts that dismantled three urban districts — one each in North Texas, Houston and the Austin/San Antonio area — that heavily favored Democrats. Two South Texas swing districts were reconfigured to be more favorable for Republicans.
If 2024 election results hold true in 2026, Republicans would gain five seats — the exact number Trump had requested.
“The trickery and the power grab became so obvious,” said Rep. Barbara Gervin-Hawkins, a San Antonio Democrat on the House redistricting committee.
The House redistricting committee held one final round of public testimony on the maps before approving and sending them to the House floor. It was during that 15-hour hearing that House Democrats crossed a threshold — enough had agreed they would be willing to leave the state in order to block a vote.
The decision
Wu, who fellow House members elected as their caucus chair in 2024, said that as House Democrats weighed whether to break quorum, he stressed that they would make the decision together, not as an edict.
To be sure, Wu said he was in favor of breaking quorum. And in the process, Democrat representatives set up a system of “whips,” representatives who regularly gauged their colleagues’ feelings about breaking a quorum.
When Wu counted 51 members willing to abscond from the state, the whips began making calls telling Democrats to pack their bags.
Rep. Mihaela Plesa was tending her rose and vegetable garden in North Dallas on Friday when she got the call.
“I immediately was taken back to the stories my grandparents told me about how they had to flee Romania and how they had to fight back against fascism,” Plesa said.
Rep. Vince Perez was in his backyard in El Paso playing with his dogs when he got the call on Friday night.
“I was probably one of the last ones to get the call,” the first-term lawmaker said. “As a new member, I’m maybe at the bottom of the totem pole.”
Rep. James Talarico, D-Austin, was studying the maps at his Capitol office on Saturday when he got the call.
“You have to be OK knowing that you’re going to get asked to leave with not a lot of notice,” Talarico said.
Midday Sunday, Aug. 3, Democrats from across the state were en route to Illinois, Massachusetts and New York. By the early evening, their flight became public.
The backlash and threats
By the time House Democrats were in front of cameras alongside Pritzker, who assisted them by finding lodging and meeting spaces, the backlash had already begun.
Attorney General Ken Paxton said he would “hunt down” absent Democrats. Abbott said he would use the courts to remove them from office if they didn’t return in time for the scheduled vote on the redrawn congressional maps.
After it became clear on Aug. 4 that enough Democrats had left to halt business in the House, Speaker Dustin Burrows issued civil warrants for their arrest that have empowered state law enforcement to detain and force lawmakers to return to the Capitol.
In Illinois, Pritzker hailed House Democrats’ decision to leave the state as a “righteous act of courage.”
In the following days, leading Illinois lawmakers would join them at press conferences in an effort to draw more attention to redistricting. Other Texas Democrats did the same in Massachusetts and New York.
Democrats were scrambling to schedule regular news briefings on their efforts. But then on Wednesday morning, a bomb threat derailed their publicity blitz.
They canceled a news conference with Illinois Sen. Dick Durbin and began reevaluating their security.
It was a rude awakening that came after a pro-Trump media outlet exposed their location on social media. Multiple members said the bomb threat evoked the killing of Minnesota lawmaker Rep. Melissa Hortman and her husband Mark Hortman.
Rep. Donna Howard, D-Austin, had traveled to Illinois with her 4-year-old grandson. Howard is his primary caregiver.
“I would have been scared just for my own self,” Howard said. “To have my grandson here made it especially traumatic, because I would obviously not want to have done anything that would have put him in danger.”
For the next two days, they remained confined to the Q-Center — a spartan conference center in St. Charles where representatives slept on twin-sized beds in rooms that reminded some of tiny cruise ship cabins. In Austin, Abbott filed paperwork with the Texas Supreme Court to remove Wu from office. Paxton announced an investigation into how Democrats were paying for their travels.
Sen. John Cornyn contacted the FBI, calling on the federal law enforcement agency to track down House Democrats.
The extent of the FBI’s work is unclear. The agency has declined to comment. Cornyn said agents in San Antonio and Austin were activated to assist state law enforcement.
Some Democrats said the threats only steeled their resolve. Others called it bullying.
Gervin-Hawkins, the chair of the Texas Legislative Black Caucus, wondered whether Republicans’ actions might cause permanent damage in a chamber where friendships form across party lines despite stark differences on policy.
“How can I face colleagues who are now trying to put a target on my back for getting hurt or for getting me arrested, and say that’s OK?” she said.
The endgame
At a bricklayers’ union hall in Elmhurst, Ill., on Friday, House Democrats held their first public appearance since the bomb threat and Cornyn’s announcement that the FBI was tracking them.
The day before, they had secretly moved their operations from the Q-Center to an undisclosed location in the Chicago area.
Their press event was muted. Its location was only provided to media members who they had verified. At least two Democrats left in the middle of the event. And by its end, lawmakers and their staff outnumbered news media nearly 2-to-1.
House Democrats are cognizant that even if they can stop redistricting during this special session, Abbott has the ability to call another session immediately. The governor has said as much and mused that Republicans could seek to flip even more congressional seats if Democrats continue to push back.
Talarico, who is mulling seeking the Democratic nomination for U.S. Senate in 2026, said the quorum break has delayed his decision on whether he will jump into the race. When asked about how Democrats would respond to repeated special sessions, he referenced the 2021 quorum break.
Democrats had fled to Washington to stop a sweeping conservative election bill. When they finally returned, some of Democrats’ most reviled pieces of policy had been stripped from the bill.
“By shining a national and international spotlight on that voter suppression bill, it pressured Texas Republicans to take the worst parts out,” he said.
Rep. Vikki Goodwin, an Austin Democrat running for lieutenant governor, said that Democrats have at least slowed down redistricting.
“The more that people become aware of the situation, the more that will have an impact in the 2026 elections,” Goodwin said.
At the bricklayers’ union hall, Goodwin watched a livestream of House Democrats’ main event of the day. About 2,000 miles away in Sacramento, Calif., Gov. Gavin Newsom, alongside a handful of Texas Democrats, said his state would redistrict its seats to counteract anything done in Texas.
Newsom was the first of several blue state governors that House Democrats have lobbied to definitively state he would pursue a partisan gerrymander in favor of Democrats. Democratic House members also visited New York Gov. Kathy Hochul.
Vice President JD Vance headed to Indiana last week to lobby for that state to pursue redistricting. Republicans in Florida have also begun an effort to redraw congressional lines.
Texas Democrats have said redrawing districts in their state would trigger a redistricting arms race. That now appears to be underway.
Correction: This article has been corrected to indicate that Rep. Barbara Gervin-Hawkins is the chair of the Texas Legislative Black Caucus

The Latest: From Illinois, Texas House Democrats say their redistricting fight is a fight for America
AUSTIN — Business in the Republican-dominated Texas House screeched to a halt in its third week of a special legislative session Monday when Democrats no-showed a critical vote on a GOP-driven plan to redraw congressional districts to further conservatives’ agenda in Washington.
The Texas House sent state troopers to look for them in all corners of the state after House Speaker Dustin Burrows was unable to call a vote on House Bill 4, by Rep. Todd Hunter, R-Corpus Christi.
A roll call shortly after 3 p.m. revealed that there were only 90 state representatives on the House floor - 10 short of the number legally required to do official business, such as vote on legislation. Those who stayed behind were allowed to leave the chamber while the House stood in recess until 1 p.m. on Tuesday.
“Come back and fulfill your duty, because this House will not sit quietly while you obstruct the work of the people,” Burrows said in remarks from the House floor.
Burrows did not reveal the number of representatives who showed up, but thanked them in remarks from the floor and blasted the “dereliction of duty” shown by those who left.
“Let me begin by commending the members who did show up, those who answered the call, honored their oath and came here ready to work for the people of Texas,” he said. “Your presence speaks volumes. You understand that there are issues before us.”
HB 4, which the Democrats are bent on killing, would shift five congressional districts in Texas from Democrat to Republican – a desire of President Donald Trump as he hopes to maintain control of the U.S. House of Representatives in the 2026 midterm elections.
Democrats say it’s illegal and marginalizes voters of color.
‘We’re happy to go back to the state of Texas this afternoon if the priority is flood relief,” said State Rep. Rafael Anchía, D-Dallas, speaking to The Dallas Morning News near Chicago. “But what we don’t want to do is participate in an illegal act of violating the Voting Rights Act.”
On motions from Rep. Charlie Geren, R-Fort Worth, and more than a dozen other Republicans, the House voted 86-6 along partisan lines to allow Burrows to sign civil warrants for the Texas Department of Public Safety to start looking for Democrats who may still be in the state.
Five Democrats were on the House floor at roll call and voted against sending troopers after their colleagues.
The DPS has the authority to compel their return to the House under threat of arrest as long as they haven’t crossed state lines.
“I’m here to work, and I’m very disappointed in my colleagues who are not here to work. It’s very simple,” said Rep. John McQueeny, R-Fort Worth, who is serving his first term in office.
Other Republicans expressed frustration as well, sending videos from the chamber floor and decrying their decision to flee.
“I do find it funny that I hear from a lot of those colleagues, ‘We don’t want to operate like D.C.,’” said Rep. James Frank, R-Wichita Falls. “Then why don’t they then stop taking orders from D.C.?”
House Democrats Sunday left for Illinois, gathering at a convention center to make their case against redrawing the lines when there was pressing, unrelated business that needed to be done.
During a Monday appearance on CNN, John Bucy said the quorum break is intended to highlight the issue for people across the country.
“This isn’t a Texas Fight. This is an American fight,” Bucy said. “It’s starting in Texas, but if this happens, all Americans will suffer and so we must stop it. And we’re asking all Americans to pay attention to what’s happening, to rise up and help us resist Donald Trump right now.”
The Democrats, some of whom are also in Boston and Albany, N.Y., are expected to stay away from the Capitol until the special legislative session called by Abbott ends on Aug. 19.
Back home on Monday, Republican state leaders railed against the Democrats’ political maneuver, which they said would only delay the inevitable passage of the legislation and kill other bills – including flood relief and property tax reform.
Gov. Greg Abbott continued his public drumbeat, bashing the Democrats for standing in the way of legislation and threatening to call for their removal from office, calling their tactic “an abandonment or forfeiture of an elected state office.”
Bucy said Democrats weren’t afraid of Abbott or Attorney General Ken Paxton, who could start removal proceedings and has threatened to have the Democrats arrested.
“We’re here running into the fight to stand up for our democracy,” Bucy said. “That’s what we’re doing, and we’ll continue to fight as long as it takes. We are here to kill this special session and that’s what we’re going to do.”
Abbott called the special session to deal with a list of 18 items. The bills sitting on the table – flood relief, a ban on retail THC, and other measures – could have, in fact, passed easily had they been brought up before the redistricting map bill, which Democrats warned could blow up the session.
Republicans chose instead to move the controversial new maps first, in what appears to be a tactic to pressure Democrats into staying for the vote – or else take the blame for shirking the flood victims of their due relief and canning other popular measures.
Later on Monday afternoon, about one hundred people showed up to protest outside of the Texas Governor’s Mansion. U.S. Democratic Reps. Greg Casar and Lloyd Doggett, who both represent Austin, spoke at the rally.
The map being considered by the Legislature could force Casar and Doggett to face each other in a Democratic primary for the lone Democratic district in Central Texas.
Neither Casar or Doggett addressed the potential primary at the protest. Instead, they applauded the Democrats who left the state in protest of the map.
Doggett also said that the quorum break has resulted in more Americans being aware of the mid-decade redistricting effort in Texas.
“As far as I’m concerned, they’ve already achieved success in bringing to the attention of the American people that this is even bigger than Texas,” Doggett said.
One of the protesters who showed up Monday was Tammy Conrad, 63, a public school teacher.
Even if the new map ends up passing, despite the quorum break and the protests, Conrad said it’s important to speak out.
“If we don’t stand up every time someone tries to take our power away, we’re not going to have any power left.”
Phillip Jankowski and Joseph Morton contributed to this report.

argos_summary: Texas House Republicans are advancing flood relief bills following the deadly July 4 floods, but a Democratic boycott has left the chamber without the necessary quorum to vote. The Democrats are using this tactic to block a controversial redistricting proposal that could shift several congressional seats from Democratic to Republican control, which they argue violates the Voting Rights Act. The situation has escalated, with threats of arrest against absent Democrats and increased tensions as both parties prepare for potential legal battles.
